author: Nicole J.R.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2018
review_content: The item arrived on time and was firmly packaged. All the pieces were included and nothing was bent, scratched or torn. It also comes with a black plastic tray to hold the money as well. The instructional booklet was easy to follow and the board is firm; however, it folds in four so it doesn't lay completely flat. Pennsylvania Railroad will stick up a bit and it's a hard crease on the B & O Railroad. I wouldn't advice being crafty by using super glue, because then it won't fold properly making the board even worse. It has to fold where the creases are, unless you plan on having it remain flat. This isn't the original version of Monopoly, I knew that based on the price, but the goal for me was to have family fun time. There were a few new tokens, T-Rex, the ducky, and the penguin which are fine when you're playing with children. For those adults who played the original monopoly and were used to being the horse, iron or shoe, theses tokens are NOT included.If you're looking for the tradition of the game, this is not for the version for you. (remember, the original board folded in two, this one does not) In addition, the Chance and Community Chest cards are also different in style, and the money is slightly smaller. But all in all, it is a fun game for the family. Although my family and I have played this game a few times, for many hours, and enjoyed it, I gave it four stars because of the fold and creases on the railroads and the inability to lay completely flat without assistance. But overall it serves its purpose.

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2018
review_content: This is the only "classic" monopoly game I could find but it's not as classic of a version as I remember as a child.  The tokens are cheaper material and not the same as in the original game. I miss the thimble and some of the other player tokens but not a big deal.There are not nearly as many houses and hotels as what you would expect but if you read the game rules, you'll understand why.  The rulebook included in this game is different from the original (at least from my rememberance of the original). This game says no money ever goes in free parking and you must have 4 houses on EACH of your property sets before you can build a hotel. Both of those rules are different from how we played the game when I was growing up.The property cards, chance, and community chest cards came all mixed up so it took a few minutes to sort through all the cards to get them in the right piles. The cards are thin and feel a bit cheaper than I would've liked.All-in-all it's a great game that is as close to the classic version as I've been able to find for a while.  It can take a few hours to complete a game which makes it perfect for a snow-day or lazy weekend night with the kids.

author: karen straiger
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2019
review_content: I hated this game growing up, however, decided to re-buy and give it another chance as I am 36 with two kids now. I bought this game a few months ago, however, decided, upon seeing misleading commercials of people enjoying themselves while playing this game(???) decided it was time I shared my thoughts with the world. This game was not worth the seventeen dollars I paid for it and the quality certainly was NOT worth my son's well-being or my marriage. My husband ended up enjoying this game and forced my kids to play it. My son has a congenital disorder that delays his learning and never was able to truly grasp the concept of the game. When no one was watching, he ended up eating all the metal characters in the game, when we found out, we rushed him to the ER and found that the pieces had cut into parts of his stomach and now, on top of helping with the numerous issues he has from his congenital disorder, he now has to eat all of his food out of a feeding tube for the next five months while his stomach heals. This incident has caused me to resent my husband for wanting to play the game and we are filing for divorce in may due to both his negligence and Haribo's. SHAME on you all.
title: tearing my family APART

author: Michael Katzenbach
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2019
review_content: This review is to notify anyone thinking of purchasing this “version” of Monopoly, beware.  They’ve made some changes to the design in certain areas so if you are gonna buy this thinking it’s the Classic version, it’s not.  It’s a modern design.  Here’s a list of the major changes:1) Most of the game pieces have been changed/updated2) The property cards are now the same size/dimensions as the Chance and Community Chest cards and the info on them is slightly different to accommodate this3) There is a new Community Chest card4) All the houses and hotels are significantly smaller (this change really bothered me)5) There a new money holder for the banker (I actually like this change)6) The money seems somewhat the same.  The colors might be more vibrant7) The instructions for the game now come in all-color unfoldable booklet (I like this too)8) The dice are significantly smaller as well (I hated this change the most)So, if you’re a purist like myself and prefer the versions from the 70s, 80s or 90s, don’t get this version.  You’ll have to look on eBay for those
title: Not the same design as previous versions

The money amounts and denomitions have been changed, none of the rules.  Property values changed. Monopoly has been consistant for over fifty years.  Not interested in a broken knock off.
